Detailed Description

A message which may be literal or localizable using a message-resource bundle.

A WMessage holds a string to be displayed. All Wt widgets use WMessage for this purpose.

In its simplest form, a WMessage is a literal string, which may be implicitly constructed from a std::string or a c-style string (const char *).

By using the static functions WMessage::tr() or WWidget::tr(), one may construct an localized message. The key argument is used to retrieve its current value from the application's message-resource bundles. Arguments in the message, denoted using {n} for the n'th argument, may be substituted by arguments set using arg(int) and arg(std::string).

By calling WApplication::refresh(), the contents of every WMessage must be refreshed by the owner (and this is done so for all Wt widgets that own a WMessage), by calling refresh();

See also:
WApplication::messageResourceBundle()

WApplication::locale()

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Wt::WMessage::WMessage (  const wchar_t *  value = 0  ) 
 

Construct a literal message.

Use this implicit constructor for setting literal, non-localized, text to be displayed by widgets.

Careful! The meaning of this constructor is different from the WMessage(const char *value) constructor prior to version Wt 2.0.0. See the release notes how to port your application.

Wt::WMessage::WMessage (  const std::wstring  value  ) 
 

Construct a literal message.

Use this implicit constructor for setting literal, non-localized, text to be displayed on widgets.

Careful! The meaning of this constructor has changed in Wt 2.0.0. See the release notes how to port your application.

Member Function Documentation

WMessage & Wt::WMessage::arg (  int  value  ) 
 

Add a value for the next positional integer argument.

In the resource, the n-th argument is reffered to as using '{n}'. For example: a resource message '{1} bought {2} apples in the shop.' with first argument value 'Bart' and second argument value '5' becomes: 'Bart bought 5 apples in the shop.'.

WMessage & Wt::WMessage::arg (  const std::wstring  value  ) 
 

Add a value for the next positional string argument.

In the resource, the n-th argument is reffered to as using '{n}'. For example: a resource message '{1} bought {2} apples in the shop.' with first argument value 'Bart' and second argument value '5' becomes: 'Bart bought 5 apples in the shop.'.

const std::string Wt::WMessage::key (   )  const [inline]
 

Get the key for this message.

When the message is a literal message, the result is undefined.

bool Wt::WMessage::literal (   )  const [inline]
 

Is this a literal message?

Returns true for a literal message, false for a localized message.

bool Wt::WMessage::refresh (   ) 
 

Refresh the message.

Returns whether the value has changed.

WMessage Wt::WMessage::tr (  const char *  key  )  [static]
 

Construct a localized message with the specified key.

The key is looked up in the application message resource bundles. If the key cannot be resolved, the value is set to ??key??.

const std::wstring Wt::WMessage::value (   )  const
 

Get the current value.

For a literal message, returns the literal value, and for a localized message, returns the current localized value. This does not result in a lookup in the message resource bundles.
